_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SYSTEM DESCRIPTION.  The MMPP Manatee Expansion Project provides five additional electrical generating units on the property of the FPL Manatee Power Plant.  These five units include four combustion turbine-generators, and one steam turbine-generator.  Nox emissions of the combustion turbines are reduced through the use of selective catalytic reduction.  That process consumes ammonia.  At this site, the ammonia is provided in anhydrous form.

The anhydrous ammonia is stored in one 20,000 gallon steel storage tank, surrounded by a concrete retaining wall.  Ammonia is delivered by tanker truck in liquid form.  The maximum level to which it is filled is 86%.  In the tank, the ammonia is stored as liquid under pressure.  Two 100% capacity vaporizers are provided to ensure pressure is maintained at lower temperatures.  Pressure will vary from 80 to 300 psig.

Ammonia vapor is transported via pressure to each heat recovery steam generator's ammonia injection skid, where the ammonia is diluted with air prior to injection into the flue gas upstream of the catalyst.

OPERATOR ORGANIZATION.  Martin-Manatee Power Partners is a limited liability corporation formed by parent companies Zachry Construction Corporation and Black & Veatch for the purpose of engineering, procuring, and constructing the expansion of the Manatee power plant.  As a part of its contractual obligations to owner FPL, MMPP must operate the facility for three months.  It is under this obligation and temporary operating scenario that this RMP is being filed.

PREVENTION PROGRAM.  

MMPP and it?s parent companies have a long-established very high expectation regarding safety and environmental protection.  The following documents were established at the outset for the Manatee Expansion Project:

Safety Recovery Plan
Hazardous Energy Control Procedure
Site Emergency Response Plan
Site Specific Safety and Training Manual
Site Environmental Control Plan

The following  letter from Zachry Construction Corporation P

resident John B. Zachry is an excerpt from the Safety Recovery Plan.  It is provided here to illustrate the Company?s dedication and commitment to safety:

CORPORATE SAFETY PHILOSOPHY

LETTER FROM THE PRESIDENT


To all employees,

The philosophy by which we operate our Company has several components that are just as relevant and important today as they were when the company was founded.  Most important among these is a concern for the well being of all our employees and a desire to create a work environment that values the safety and health of our workforce above all else.  By all established and recognized metrics, we have been quite successful over the years in meeting our safety goals.  We have not, however, been as successful as we would like to be and, clearly, not as successful as we can be.  Not until we identify any potential hazards that might exist at our worksite, and manage our work such that our employees are not at risk, can we be truly satisfied.  We must accept nothing less from ourselves.

To achieve this ultimate goal requires not only active participation in our safety processes by all employees; it requires constant commitment and leadership from everyone.  It is critical that all employees feel a strong sense of responsibility, empowerment, and accountability when it comes to ensuring that everyone works safely.  Only by working together, with every employee doing their part, can we make safety incidents a thing of the past.  Without question, safety is everyone?s responsibility.

Working safely is not always easy or expedient, but it is always smart and, more importantly, it is always the right thing to do.  It is also an integral part of the way Zachry Company will conduct its business.  Additionally, there is an expectation that all employees will conduct themselves in a way that consistently demonstrates proper and safe behavior.  I am confident that, together, we can continue to improve our performance and meet every goal we set for oursel

ves.  Thank you for your support and keep working safely.




John B. Zachry

===============================================================

Anhydrous Ammonia is covered at this site under the OSHA PSM rule.  Specific to this RMP, the prevention program at MMPP consists of (1) Engineering Controls, (2) Establishment of safe Standard Operating Procedures and Training, (3) Process Hazard Assessment (PHA), and Establishment of Management of Change Process.  These are described in more detail in the Prevention Program Description.

The overall approach to minimizing risk of accidental release is based on a foundation of sound engineering design,  careful construction with high attention to QA/QC practices, development of appropriate standard operating procedures, and training for affected employees.  Design has included features such as engineered controls to prevent overfilling of the tank, breakaway valve stations to minimize release should a truck pull away before uncoupling, monitoring stations for detection of accidental releases, and water sprays to help minimize migration of vapor releases.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.  This is a new facility with no prior history with anhydrous ammonia.  There have been no accidental releases of ammonia at the time of this filing.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.  The employees of MMPP and neighboring FPL Manatee Station are not trained as first responders.  In the event of a large-scale release, site personnel will follow an established emergency response plan which includes notification of MMPP management, FPL management, 911, local emergency responders, and previously identified firms with the capability and willingness to respond to anhydrous ammonia releases.

Local emergency personnel have been involved in training provided by MMPP regarding the anhydrous ammonia facility and its potential risks.

All site personnel have received training.  Those without a direct involvement in the operations and maintenance of the anhydrous

ammonia system have received overview level training?what are the hazards, how can they be identified, and what to do in the event of a release.  Personnel who may have to enter a high concentration area inn order to isolate a system with a manual valve, for example,  have received 24-hour training.  They must remain clean-shaven at the point of SCBA mask contact, and have been instructed in the use of the appropriate protective PPE and SCBA.

MMPP considers the delivery of ammonia at the site to be one of the highest risk periods..  Unloading will be done by the ammonia vendor by their qualified personnel.  As an additional safety measure, MMPP will station a trained person, with protective suit and SCBA to observe the unloading and intervene if necessary.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.  A PHA process was undertaken as a part of the RMP.  Identified issues were considered and addressed.  As this RMP is being filed prior to initial arrival of anhydrous ammonia on site, there are no planned changes to improve safety at this time.
